docs.lead_paragraph: The president's elderly stepgrandmother brought him an oxtail fly whisk, a mark of power at home in Kenya. Cousins journeyed from the South Carolina town where the first lady's great-great-grandfather was born into slavery, while the rabbi in the family came from the synagogue where he had been commemorating Martin Luther King's Birthday. The president and first lady's siblings were there, too, of course: his Indonesian-American half-sister, who brought her Chinese-Canadian husband, and her brother, a black man with a white wife. When President Barack Obama was sworn in on Tuesday, he was surrounded by an extended clan that would have shocked past generations of Americans and instantly redrew the image of a first family for future ones.
docs.abstract: Pres Barack Obama's family is microcosm of nation's diversity; relatives on his father's side are from Kenya and Michelle Obama's great-great grandfather was born into slavery; family includes whites, blacks, Asians, Christians, Muslims and Jews who speak plethora of languages; no longer are they disparate kin from pages of his memoir, but embodiment of new president's promise of change; America has, until now, always been more diverse than its first families; very few Obama family members are wealthy; America celebrates inauguration of first black president, but Obama narrative is complex; photos; family tree (L)

byline.original: By JODI KANTOR; Jeffrey Gettleman contributed reporting from Kenya. Kitty Bennett contributed research

headline.main: Nation's Many Faces in Extended First Family

docs.snippet: The new president was sworn in while surrounded by a clan that redrew the image of the first family....

docs.lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama is sometimes compared to Jacqueline Kennedy, but she may now have something in common with another first lady, Eleanor Roosevelt. Mrs. Roosevelt became an honorary member of the Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority, a historically black organization founded in 1908, and the group announced this week at its centennial convention that Mrs. Obama had agreed to join. The sorority said that once Mrs. Obama was formally inducted into the organization, which has 225,000 members, she could not become a member of any of the other ''Divine Nine'' organizations, as black sororities and fraternities are often called. Other honorary members of Alpha Kappa Alpha include the poet Maya Angelou, the late Coretta Scott King and the former astronaut Mae Jemison.
docs.abstract: Michelle Obama will becoma honorary member of Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority, historically black organization founded in 1908; photos (M)
